Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Foie

icx337WF6PWUr56wR0NLdQ.text: Why would anyone go to Braddock for dinner?  There is one very good reason....SUPERIOR MOTORS.  This is one of the best casual, yet elegant dinner restaurants in the Pittsburgh area.  Staff is knowledgable, helpful and friendly.  The visit begins in the parking lot when we experienced smell of the wood-fire coming from the kitchen.  It has comfortable, pleasant seating with a full bar that is well stocked with a generous, well organized "vintage and domestic" wine list.  I can only say our meals (4) were each "extraordinary".  The short menu, downloadable in advance (and recommended), helps you to choose dinner.  The menu includes a nice variety of mouthwatering treats for your palate from both sea and land.   I highly recommend a trip/adventure in Braddock to enjoy a Superior dinner.

1kHJ2ZKdBWjC5NieThR2Xg.text: The atmosphere and the industrial atmosphere enticed me before I even walked in. I enjoyed the pleasant and proactive staff that were entertaining and attentive. The food was delicious. The wine menu has something for everyone. There wasn't much to offer when it came to soft drinks but the basics is all you need. I was impressed with the cocktails and the passion put into the place. The chicken was seasoned well. The cabbage was cooked just right. It wasn't too loud or too quiet. The smoked chocolate dessert was most definitely the star of the show here. I can't wait to come back. Maybe next time I'll go for the salmon. I'm not courageous enough for the octopus.

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States

3AbwrDlyAe-N1tLaFVuEnA.text: This was one of the best meals ever!! My boyfriend and I were in braddock and decided we'd try to get a seat at the bar here on a whim. We got a seat right next to the kitchen and it was so cool to watch them. The chef came up and talked to us about a the new cabbage dish he created and brought us one on the house. The whole kitchen staff was talkative and super nice. Everything we tried was outstanding..the gnocchi was unreal and the beef tartare was served with seaweed to roll it up with and it was unlike any beef tartare we've ever had. My boyfriend had the pork belly which was melt in your mouth. I had the scallops and they were cooked perfectly. The smoked potatoes we got as a side and we couldn't figure out what was in the sauce but it was incredible. For dessert we had the meringue and chocolate, both delicious and a perfect ending. The whole meal was so flavorful and innovative. If you have a chance to go here DEFINITELY do it!!

bGS-0x-NvB51ZbbQomY75A.text: The menu is innovative and interesting.  Nice decor but loud.  Worth the drive, especially if you like different food.

eZjFRXYg_gF4SaNKP56rXg.text: The service was excellent but that's the best I can say. The food was fair but it was unrecognizable. The wine selection was limited. No pinot noir. The price was ridiculously expensive for what we ordered.

DDzUMI3FjqwNWmHeyOOtKA.text: Came to Superior Motors on a Saturday night in September while visiting my parents here in the city. We had all loved Salt of the Earth and had been following Kevin Sousa's every move, waiting anxiously for this restaurant to open. My mom had the opportunity to eat dinner here a month earlier and had told us the food lived up to the hype. The atmosphere and service was great, bt this time around, the food was only OK. We started with the beef tartare, octopus and foie gras torchon. The beef  in the tartare was mixed with crispy rice crackers, topped with bonito flakes and served with nori paper. Put together, the asian flavors way overpowered the beef. The octopus was cooked well and had a nice smokey flavor but lacked acid/heat to balance out the creamy, smokiness of the dish. The foie gras was incredibly sweet and would have made a great dessert but felt out of place as an appetizer.  Our thoughts on the main courses were similar to the appetizers. The pork dish, topped with trout roe and dashi potatoes tasted more like fish than pork. The lamb was OK and the rigatoni was lacking in acid, similar to the octopus. We got the sorbet for desert which was also OK. Our waitress forgot our coffees and when they finally arrived was nice enough to removed them from our bill as an apology. All in all, it seemed like Kevin Sousa was trying to do too much. The manager came over at the end of the meal to ask how things were and we were honest. He was polite and listened to what we had to say. The last kicker was when we got the bill. Part of the wine list is right justified on the page and my 69 year old father had read the bolded number as the price of the bottle of wine. Oh no - that's just the number they assign to the wine. The actual price is on the left - not a natural place for your eye to rest. We had the Molly Dooker wine which my Dad thought was a steal at $45. Nope. It was actually 81 and showed up on the bill that way!

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Right justified wine list. Be careful - the price is all the way on the left.

GjROv-5uSA10cIHBzHsnNQ.text: This was truly a unique gourmet dining experience and thoroughly enjoyable.   The chef's dishes were outstanding and the staff attentive and helpful. We will return eager to enjoy the chef's creativity. Though prices are not for the faint of heart, the seven different menu items the three of us shared and enjoyed were worth every cent.   I cannot wait to return

4rDD-JJw63egjmZWABcdbA.text: I can't say a single bad thing about our dinner here.   Got the tartare and skate apps (both awesome), the cavatelli (good) and lamb (incredible) entrees, and the panna cotta dessert (fantastic and I don't even like dessert). The mezcal cocktail is a standout, as well.  Service was incredible -- our server, Anthony, is reeeaaallly good at his job. And at the end of our meal the GM, Chris, offered to take us into the kitchen and show us around. We chatted with him for a bit back there and had the opportunity to tell Kevin that our meal was an all-timer. Top to bottom genuinely great hospitality.  My wife and I cannot wait to go back.

juW1ydsE1raUZkV74Fv_2g.text: It's just not good. First, the minute we walked into the place, the overwhelming smell of fish took my breath away. It smelled like we walked into Wholey's and I had to mouth-breath the entire time. The food is all bland. Salad was overdressed and not a single thing stood out where I would want to get it again. There was an octopus appetizer that had potential, but it was smothered in a grey sauce with corn....very unappealing. I will not be back. Plus four of us for dinner with splitting apps and dessert and drinks was still $300

UNUbS2j3zK-CGSB3bXYyJA.text: This is an upscale restaurant and it mostly lives up to it.   PROS: Easy parking, nice decor, service is what you would expect it to be. Food is tasty but, as expected for a restaurant of this caliber, the servings are small and expensive. Foie gras appetizer was delicious. Venison and pork were both very good.  CONS: Service was slow between courses. They have some seating that is lounge seating which makes it a bit harder to eat. I would suspect most people would rather sit at a table so you don't have to bend over to eat but that could just be a matter of opinion.  Overall, an excellent place to try for a special occasion but not somewhere I'll go back to any time soon.

3bIoLWcitFKwwszutnxFag.text: We were seated at the bar because of the large crowd.  The bartender/server was friendly and knowledgeable, however the service was on the slow side.  We got a view into the kitchen and the staff was intense and focused.  The food was excellent from the octopus and salad appetizers to the duck and chicken entrees.  Both my wife and I felt that the portions were small especially for the price.  We decided to skip the $10 desserts and go to baskin robins instead for ice cream.  I think it would be a service to its blue collar location if Superior can find a way to make their excellent product a little more accessible to their neighbors.

qaa90mdkK-TjT4t2tWLpFw.text: Went for opening night and it was an amazing experience. The staff is great from the moment you walk in til the moment you walk out the door! The food plating and atmosphere make you feel like you're on top chef haha. The beef cut like butter and was delicious. I also really enjoyed the halibut and desserts. Chris (maybe their som?)picked out a great bottle of wine for us as well. Great place for a special occasion or date night.

9wVg2D3kMpiB1oOCdG_wrQ.text: First visit, 2 and a half weeks after opening.  Service was excellent and attentive.  For was creative and delicious.  The foie gras starter was superb.  I had the beef, which was mouthwatering.  Pretty extensive wine list.  The chocolate dessert (with mushrooms!) was fantastic.  Be prepared to ask questions about what items are on the menu.  There is a lot of interesting stuff there.

bdxXV9oU3YSKEOQWI30-eA.text: Sit at the bar and watch the action. Great food, great cocktails. The place is ever changing and top notch. If you haven't been then what are you waiting for

IJQOB8URJ9U0yC113-E-3Q.text: What an unexpected treat. I am here for a conference, and one of my colleagues who went to elementary school nearby recommended the place. I followed the recommendations of our waitress, and despite seeming like an odd combination of ingredients, I was glad I listened to her. Also, she split our checks for a very large party without any grumbling, so that was also greatly appreciated.

hH4qZlAvbxCErsDyq6A8PQ.text: So I never write on yelp but I felt I had to after going here last night. It was by far one of the best meals I've had in Pittsburgh. It is a very cool new spot. The atmosphere is very unique with minimalist furniture and artwork. We sat at the lounge seats which I loved. It's great for young couples. It feels very intimate and you get an unique view of the only steel mill left in the city. The drink list is amazing, they have an extensive wine list which you can tell they put a lot of time into choosing the specific wines. Their seasonal cocktails were also unreal! The food was beautifully presented, you almost didn't want to eat it because you didn't want to ruin the artwork. But it tasted unreal too. My two favorite dishes were the beef tartare appetizer and beef main dish. I could eat both of those every day. Lastly, the staff who worked provided amazing service. Someone different was always checking in and having unique conversation with you. I will definitely be going back for special occasions.

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Desserts
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Beef dish
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Chicken dish

Q4cH0mEfsvDJLuFZpcgAVg.text: Everyone was so warm and accommodating, from changing our table because of accessibility issues to being patient and gracious in fielding questions. The spring pea starter was just incredible and members in our party loved the chicken and veal. Wish I still lived here-I'd be a regular!

IdVEfPdp2sUIAaI6rsYjIQ.text: I'm giving Superior Motors some leeway since they just opened, but feel the need to mention some missteps that could dampen others' experiences too. The biggest one was that we were advised to order 3 entrees to split between the 2 of us, in addition to an appetizer.  This was way too much food and we agreed that it seemed like an upcharge tactic.  To repeat: you do not need to order more than one entree for yourself, the portions are totally normal!    There was also a point-of-sale error that affected us and the couple next to us, too: we noticed an extra entree charge on our bill, pointed it out, and then waited 15-20 minutes before getting a corrected bill and our card back.  I know that these things happen, especially when you're just opening, but the staff didn't seem very apologetic and coupled with the misleading advice above (plus a mid-meal stretch where we tried in vain to get our server's attention) it just didn't seem like they cared very much.  I really enjoyed Salt of the Earth and was looking forward to trying Kevin Sousa's new venture but our experience was disappointing.  While good, I can't say that our meal (beef tartare appetizer and beef, pork, and halbut entrees) was terribly unique or memorable... sorry, I won't be rushing back for a second try.

XZdykR2g9kk5YSG-NURJlg.text: My girlfriend and I had a really fun date night here.  Generally speaking, I'm not high-end food guy - know that from the start.  The venison was delicious.  The soup was interesting and creative but I wouldn't order it again.  The tuna was okay.  I loved the bourbon cocktail, wine, and the whole scene was a lot of fun.  The wait staff was also great.  Super fun and helpful!  I'd recommend it to anyone for a great night!  But stick with the red meat and the bourbon.

aMhiA22x89EYcCWzCCVAGw.text: Went here on a Friday night because we didn't want to cook and I wish we had just stayed home. We tried the rice cakes with tempeh first. Tempeh was good flavor/texture-wise. The rice cakes were "eh", I kind of felt like I was eating a cotton swab. We also tried the fluke with gnocchi & wow was it disappointing. The gnocchi was either overboiled by about ten minutes or just terrible to begin with. The gnocchi literally were flavorless mush balls. The fish had no taste really. We also had the scallop with puffed rice which was visually appealing but just OK. Nothing about it stood out aside from the fact that the scallop was fresh.The sunchoke was the only truly delicious dish I had. The flavors in it worked very well and the sunchoke was fried nicely. For the price, I was expecting solid, delicious food and was so disappointed. We didn't finish most of our food due to how lacking it was, which says a lot because the portions are very small. What's more, our server didn't seem to have an interest in us because we were younger than everyone else in the restaurant and weren't dressed to the nines. Will not be going back. Everything looked much better than it tasted.

vihKhSFtYuUt37RuxUVKyg.text: We loved it! The service and food were both perfect. Looking forward to going back each season to see what changes. There are also additions being finished (theater and event spaces) that looked interesting.

p08e_V3FuaGq1gMarTOqig.text: Blew my mind. Tuna tartar was perfect. My steak was tender and juicy  and still hot till the last bite.  But the smoked chocolate was the best dessert I've ever tasted. It was a great experience.

LZWTZW56NFJsEDRbWQwIHw.text: I was absolutely blown away by my meal. Started off with the punch cocktail which had notes of cinnamon and lime- a good sipper. First course was the salmon tartare and it was phenomenal. It was so fresh and I thoroughly enjoyed it. For the main course I had the short ribs. Next time I'm there I can't wait to order it again. The beef literally melted in my mouth, paired perfectly with fresh Brussels sprouts and polenta, it was almost like eating a meal at my grandmothers. Dessert called for the Pavlove- an orangey meringue with fermented fruit and blood oranges. Spoke for some time with the manager(?) and he was hilarious and down to earth.  Even had a chance to thank the chef for my wonderful meal. I will definitely definitely be returning very soon.

YUxyctoce-vmk3wby3wQXw.text: I've been waiting for a long time for this restaurant and I was absolutely not disappointed. I had the Korean rice cakes tempeh, lamb, and sourdough poundcake and they were all excellent. My companions had the monkfish, beef, pavlova and like them, too. The atmosphere is also aesthetically pleasing. Although outside of the city, the drive is not too bad and lovely if you travel by the river AND it is worth it!

cxMSEN8K5xgBy-rQ7rYE9w.text: This place is fantastic. Unpretentious, high-end, modern, new gastropub. Bartenders are cool as heck. Modern cocktails, new world wines, local beer. Plates are small, so get 5 to share.

KbYysiOmLLTtbjIyL8_X1w.text: Superior Motors is an example of hype over quality, and misappropriation of ego.  There is little to like at this disastrous project.  The people of Braddock deserve better.

R8gQk2azj7HgqeVSnIOlew.text: I am a big Kevin Sousa fan. I very much miss Union Pig & Chicken and miss Salt of the Earth. Union Pig was much more my style of eatery...    This place is probably one of the 5 best restaurants in PIT. That it sits in the shadow of the Edgar Thompson Works, in Braddock, is amazing actually if you know the area. This real estate, just a decade ago, was entirely derelict and quite dangerous. Braddocc Mayor John Fetterman, through the will and force of his personality, has made this entire ZIP code habitable again. I believe he owns the building Superior Motors is in ...   Sousa and his staff create and serve food that is flavorful, challenging, and ... if you enjoy the gourmet experience ... thrilling. I have to admit, that's not my thing at all. This is just not my kind of place. I had a steak dish when it first opened (wish I'd taken better notes, believe it was Argentenian steak of some variety - was excellent) and it was not on the menu when I returned in 12/2017.   Appetizers are all works of art. The only one that I was interested in eating was the beef tartare ... and it was excellent, 5 star.   I have had the pork dish (I don't like caviar with my pig, sorry), and it was good. Very good. I think the presentation and arrangement was superior to the dish itself. Have also had the short rib which was equally stunning. Like wow, this is astounding to behold.    You can BYOB, with a cork fee, which I always appreciate.   I have never had service matching the price of dining here. Never. I don't show up in camp pants and a Penguins jersey either(I know what you were thinking!) I know "how to eat" and "how to order" at a 5 star restaurant ... the staff here treated me like a rube. Several times, when asking questions about the menu, the server deferred and said "I'll just let you have more time to review the menu." NO, I don't need more time... I need you to answer my question. Good lord. Never encountered that sort of treatment at any of Sousa's other eateries.   Anyway, if you enjoy food as art? You will LOVE this place. If not, you won't. This is a very unique gourmet restaurant that offers truly unique and superior dishes.

YRGZHHczVrajpwXnR285dA.text: First time at Superior Motors with a group of 4 and it was great. Tried almost everything on the menu by sharing and loved it all. Top hits were Beef Tartare, Brassica and Greens and Gnocci. Main entree favs were Lamb, Beef and Halibut. Great drink selection. We did not have dessert. Shout out to our server Vondre who we loved. He brought us a complimentary Salmon and took us into the kitchen at the end of our meal. Got to see Kevin taking command of the kitchen and it made our night. Highly recommend even if the portions aren't huge as others have mentioned. Great atmosphere, would happily return. Well worth the out of the way trip for this fine dining experience.

0E8m8sPMxu1Mmv4f0E6K0A.text: Finally got out to Superior Motors - man did it live up to the hype and then some!! Was blown away by how friendly and accommodating the staff was. Before arriving I called to inquire about what entrees could be adjusted for a vegan. The woman on the phone was so happy to walk me through the menu and discuss which items could be adjusted and made vegan (several of them!--basically just omitting the cheese). All the pictures looked so good, so I knew I was in for a treat.   The restaurant itself is so clean, simple and elegant. From big half circle booths, tons of tables, to the bar, and even a back dining area, the restaurant was definitely very large. So nice that my party of four was seated at a large booth and not crammed at a four person table. Our table was ready the second we walked through the doors and our waiter arrived within moments of us sitting down. Definitely would recommend a reservation as it was quite crowded at 5 PM on a Sunday.   Our waiter walked us through the menu and was happy to describe all dishes in further detail. My table ended up ordering the beef entree, sturgeon, and mushroom risotto. Holy heck was the mushroom risotto perfection. The rye and pearl barley was a perfect al dente and really made the meal feel super hearty and filling. It was topped with just two tiny tiny slices of mushroom. My only complaint is compared to both the beef & fish entree which were quite large, the portion size of the risotto was teeny tiny--almost appetizer size. Felt that as being an entree it definitely should have been a bigger portion. Although aside from the size, the taste was absolutely exquisite. It was made vegan by omitting the goat cheese and WOW was it amazing. For dessert they had four options and our waiter advised us the further down the list you go, the less traditional the desserts became. Fortunately the coconut dessert was vegan and also last on the list, it was super unique and so very delicious. We also ordered the pear tart and my party absolutely loved it. So sweet they even put a candle on the dessert for my boyfriend's birthday. Loved everything about our meal here, and I can't wait to get back again in the near future.

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Mushroom risotto entrée - rye, pearl barley, sage, celeriac. $20. Made vegan by omitting the goat cheese—AMAZING!
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Beef entrée - polenta, brussels, mushroom, béarnaise. $36 Boyfriend LOVED every last bite.
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Loved this little cast iron table setting.

WIJZcIloALQCVdgw384WzQ.text: We brought out-of-town friends to the restaurant this past weekend.  I have been rooting for this restaurant because of what it could mean to Braddock. I had a good experience but given the price point I am not rushing back.  The food was uneven -- some very good dishes, some good and many just OK.  There are many better restaurants in Pgh at this price point. And the one glaringly bad moment of the evening was when we asked for some more bread for an appetizer (chicken liver pate) that didn't have a sufficient amount. They replied No, but we could order another appetizer. Not the right answer ever, especially given it would cost them very little and our party spent $700 that evening. Next time I want to splurge, I will choose one of my favorites in Pgh -- Cure, Poulet Bleu, Legume, Butcher in the Rye, or Morcilla.

NE23XMnBY82Ljtuun98wmA.text: Great place if you are a foodie.  Different combinations of meats and vegetables.  Don't expect normal restaurant food. Service was very good.  If you drink rose wine this is a place for you.

Heq3nEvSmlctVF5sJNX_5g.text: The restaurant is in Braddock 7 miles from Pittsburgh.  I live In town and to reserve a table you have to give a credit card. I found that a little odd but they were accommodating on changing the time for me. I visited the area late so I do not have a clear opinion  about the area. It seems nice but across this place there is a factory. There is  available parking on both sides of the restaurant and on the street. The ambience  is really nice. To open kitchen concept is very attractive . The staff is nice and our server was a little hyperactive!!! . She was informative though. We had a company of five and I tried the beer which is aged and  my husband tried a cocktail. The drinks were good. The food was a four out of five stars. We had  the steak,   the scallops and the Venison. I tried them all. The presentation was excellent. The pork and the duck were not well prepared. Again the presentation was great and the plate looked fine but the duck had the characteristic smell of an unwell prepared meat. Maybe the chef should remove these plates from the menu. The desserts were very good. Good try chef but not a five star. Sorry. I will not be back.

Jd5hqt48_gC_WS4fpn9reQ.text: I like this place a lot.  Contributing food innovation to an old neighborhood offering memories both good and bad. Small plates are perfect solution for wanting to order 5 items on the menu. A few of the highlights from the eight dishes we shared.   Chicken livers were like liver lovers ice cream. Really good. The halibut offered taste beyond this great fish. Veal and steak tartare were tasty as well. All washed down with a great Italian bottle of wine.

IuxudqR8oAuW2TNclpRfOQ.text: Wanted to like this place so much. But it is Overrated. Poorly executed menu. Terrible service. Incredibly expensive. Disappointed is an understatement.

La5gGObPBpopHZZYvVYBPw.text: More of a novelty than anything. Tiny portions of overly complicated dishes at not-so-tiny prices. Not food allergy friendly with very limited options. Clearly there is an allure to this place given its reputation and storied history, but in this case Superior Motors falls well short of the hype.

Vq3oo2cOmang8SfAjrAIpQ.text: We went for a birthday celebration. It was absolutely great! We were seated on time. The best mocktails in town! Very friendly staff. Each plate was excellent and brought the best out of each seasonal produce.   Haha, really my only complaint is I can't eat there alll the time.

Ibij81HLrh0BuCmtCvsFjg.text: It is a little pricey but everything is quite unique and delicious! I highly recommend the pretzel salad for dessert, full of flavor yet still light!

evyWL7h09RXo5hU4KjyLSg.text: I was completely taken surprise by this place!! To start off the decor and atmosphere was great! It has that mix of old and new paying homage to what used to be housed here and the neighborhood that it is in. Our waiter Will so very professional kind and knowledgeable on the food and the history of the space. Will suggested on the drink of the week. 2 1.5 ounce manhattans. One post prohibition made with rye and the other modern. The food was amazing! Plates are small so you can order a bunch for sharing. We started off with the soft shell crab and the shrimp tapenade. The Asian inspired flavor with the crab was delicious. Then had the grass fed filet and the pappardelle pasta. The filet isn't  your typical filet and our server told us that up front along with the fact that it's supposed to be served warm. I love servers who give us a heads up on items. The filet practically melted in my mouth! The pasta was a nice light accompaniment to the filet. We ended up ordering the pretzel salad for dessert. We were told by another server ( waitress) Who delivered our dessert that the mulberries were even picked next-door!  Even the girl server assistant/busser was friendly and helpful.  I cannot wait to come back and try more items!!!

seglsNEkAWa6OXU4b36Pgg.text: Wow. I wish I could dine here every day, but it's a bit spendy to become a regular place for me.  I started with drinks  the Gin, Mezcal and Tequila cocktails, I had a taste of the Rum and my god they were all so perfect. I think my favorite was the Mezcal. The server that we had was so pleasant and helped a lot with recommendations. Ordering felt like a consultative shopping experience, and whenever they brought the food out, everything was more thoroughly described to us. Guys, before this day, I have never eaten a salad that made me moan out load. The dressing was creamy and complex in flavor, I really couldn't even tell you what it was. The mushrooms melted in my mouth like no mushrooms ever have before... and there were soaked almonds in it which added yet another suprise to my dining experience. I made everyone at the table taste my salad and they looked at me like I was crazy, but after they tasted it, they understood my excitement. Moving on to the seitan... WOAH. I have never dated seitan that had such a smooth and consistent texture. The portion looked small, but seitan is quite filling so those two items were plenty for me to eat without feeling stuffed. I didnt have room for dessert, but I tasted the ice cream dish that they had. Dark chocolate garnishes on and under a lime ice cream. It was SO good and reminded me of imported chocolates that I once had. I think this is a great place for groups, or for a romantic evening with a loved one... leave your kids at home, no one wants to hear them while they're enjoying the tranquility and complexity that this restaurant has to offer.

Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Braddock greens

TZDmJbfA-_ro52UJy8fMlw.text: I'm a long-lost son of Pittsburgh. I grew up in this beat-up Steel Town. I watched jobs evaporate around me at an exponential rate. I saw people around me slip into the use of the needle. Now, I'm a twenty-something year old yuppie who comes back to Pittsburgh six or seven times a year to see my folks. This place is full of nostalgia and is meaningful to me.  As this city climbs out of the ashes, the food scene is rebounding in a really big way. It's truly symbolic watching new cuisines people would have spat at years ago become popular. My old man saw Superior Motors in a Food and Wine magazine article and sent me the link. I thought, "wow, this place is perfect for me. I'm a snobby millennial who loves this return to greatness story they're promoting."   We walked into the joint and I noticed a Tribe Called Quest vinyl out and "Push it Along" playing on their phono. I was charmed instantly.   Unfortunately, that and my vermouth were the highlight of the meal. Service was inadequate. It's heartwarming that a large portion of the work force comes from Braddock. But that doesn't compensate for the quality. The waitress gave my dad my drink. Another waitress mixed up our meal orders at the table and didn't bother to even ask. We had to correct her. They were not apologetic either.  The food reminds me of an avant-garde musician you really want to like for their sheer talent and appearances on more conventional artists' records. But you can't enjoy that artist because their aggregated skills put together make for some horrible art.  The individual items are some of my favorites. I had the diver scallops to start the meal. The scallops are served raw, which I generally dig. However, the seasoning was minimal on the scallops and the cuttlefish. I knew going in the texture on the cuttlefish would be a bit chewy but it was one of the worst textural experiences I have had during a meal. Everything is soft in the bowl. They served three pieces of some greens to add some crunch, but they were soggy. The buckwheat noodles in the ink were tasty but again soft. It just was disappointing along several dimensions.   For the main course, I had the duck. This, too, unfortunately was not fantastic. The swiss chard in cashews wasn't overwhelmingly good. It was okay but it wasn't anything I'd seek out again. The duck didn't really seem to fit with the rest of the plate, which included a swiss chard roll with rhubarb inside and pickled strawberries. Pickled strawberries were very unique. But the flavors seemed so random and nothing was cohesive. For the price of the meal, you can get better elsewhere.   Neither my parents nor I are inclined to go back. It looks like Food & Wine got caught up in the personal narrative rather than what was going on in front of them. Braddock is a dead town and even if Pittsburgh comes back bigger than ever, the location will kill this place given the quality of food they're serving. This place needs to step it up or their Kickstarter money is gonna vanish.

qzUxrRDFaVvDK00janxB7g.text: I've never ventured out to Braddock before, but I'm glad I did for this place! The vibe in here is so cool. I loved the huge windows in the front that showcase the steel mill across the street. You can tell they put a ton of thought into designing the restaurant.  To drink, I had the "Punch". It was very strong - probably a bit too strong for my taste - but still tasty. They were offering a non-vegetarian and vegetarian tasting menu for restaurant week, so we ordered one of each.   We started with a trout and carrot tartar. My favorite of the two was the trout, but the carrot was very unique! You could barely tell that it was carrot because of the smoky flavor. Next was a short rib dish and rice cakes. The short ribs were so tender and rich, and everything else in the dish was really yummy too. The rice cakes were a let down in my opinion, and I probably wouldn't order this one again. Lastly, we had a pasta dish with confit (not sure what type of meat it was) and a mushroom barley risotto dish, both of which were delicious.   We also couldn't help but try two of the desserts (the chocolate and the creme brulee). The chocolate dessert, which was recommended by our waiter, was the highlight of the night and probably one of the best desserts I've ever had. Skip the creme brulee and get two chocolate desserts.   Service was great as well - the waiter was very friendly, attentive, and gave us plenty of time to enjoy each dish. I'm looking forward to my next visit!

Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Chocolate dessert
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Pasta with confit (restaurant week)

rYeFkmEM4XOqnBYCK3y1yw.text: The food was spectacular, I would give it at 25! The ambience and restaurant organization I give a 3. The main room is super loud, our waitress had to scream over the noise, we could barely have a conversation at our booth. When we walked in, the lobby area had about 10 people waiting and staff kept going through the customers to back of house, pushing us all around the room; there was no where to stand to be out of the way.  Totally worth coming, hope they can get their ambience more refined.

BDfbelxNGwh1OtVA9OB9VA.text: My parents first ate here after seeing Superior Motors on Parts Unknown and loved it so much they booked our family after Thanksgiving dinner here for the Saturday after turkey day at 6:30pm. There is street parking but also a small parking area next door which we were able to squeeze into. The decor is very modern industrial-my husband particularly liked how the back of the bar was lit to shine on all of the bottles there.   We were immediately sat upon arrival in a cozy 5 person booth, which was on the dining side opposite from where my parents sat on their original visit. It was not too crowded but I'd recommend reservations since the holiday probably had something to do with the light crowd. Our server came over quickly, gave some menu highlights, and then left us to explore the ever-changing menu.   We ordered a bottle of Cab franc for the table which paired nicely with our (mostly red) meat entrees. I noticed they allow BYOB too but I'm not sure on the corkage fee but just an FYI for those interested. They serve homemade sourdough bread-at a cost-pre meal if requested. We dove straight into appetizers and entrees though. My parents ordered the beef tartare served with seaweed wraps. While enjoyable they said the beef tartare at Union Standard is superior (having never been I cannot share my opinion) but this version was quite spicy. I tried a forkful and thought it was ok, spicy for sure, I'm not a beef tartare fan at all, but my husband finished the dish for them since they were not too impressed. He enjoyed the spicy flavors and found the seaweed wraps to be the perfect way to wrap the tartare up for delivery to the mouth.   For entrees, 3 of us ordered the short rib dish. My mom was highly disappointed they changed the menu and didn't have the steak (best since Argentina she said-which was in February). All of us loved the short rib! The meat was super tender, the bearnaise sauce intermixed with mushroom and onions was the perfect accompaniment for the flavorful short ribs. The polenta was interesting. I'm not familiar with it but this version was in cubes with a cinnamon-like outer coating. The only miss here was the Brussels sprouts which were not cooked thoroughly and were quite hard. My dad ordered the halibut which was served with a miso broth poured on top upon its arrival to the table. Of course, no one got a taste but he said it was unique and delicious. My husband ordered the pork dish, complete with trout roe, and loved it-his plate was the first one cleaned. For dessert my husband and I shared the chocolate dessert as did my mom and dad. It was really, um, interesting. I'm a purist with chocolate so I wish the lower layer of the black sesame patty had not been there because the adzuki ice cream with chocolate ganache and the cherries was delicious! My brother ordered the panna cotta, which I wasn't able to try, but since he finished it all, that probably meant he gave his approval of the dessert.   Portions are just right-don't expect to leave overstuffed or hungry. I really enjoyed my dining experience at Superior Motors and, while it's in an area that is probably inconvenient for most of Pittsburgh, I'd still recommend taking the drive to Braddock for a superior dining experience!

Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Panna cotta-caramel, miso, hazelnut, passion fruit

Qj75T6mizr3Qc0XnDe6HpQ.text: I give this place a great rating if you need a recommendation of somewhere to go. My experience was pleasant and plan to go back if needed in future

AXAKuhVIjI_-CmxnZHOuEw.text: First of all, the atmosphere at Superior Motors is amazing. The space is unique and the bar/lounge area is very cozy. The wait staff was super friendly and attentive and our waiter even gave us a tour of the kitchen after our meal. Also, the drinks are AMAZING. Definitely order the "punch" because it's a truly beautiful drink.   Now the food...  ...everything was beautiful. I can't say enough about the presentation. However our table of 4 ordered upwards of 12 dishes and my husband and I didn't love any of them. I ordered the duck as my entree and couldn't finish it. I basically choked down a few bites because it was so expensive and I didn't want to waste it. It would have helped had the preparation method for each item been described briefly on the menu as this would have better guided my ordering decision. This food just wasn't for us...maybe that's because my taste isn't sophisticated enough for this stuff. What's worse is that this dinner was NOT cheap. So we spent a small fortune on a bunch of dishes, left unsatisfied, and drove through Wendy's on the way home.   We'd go back for drinks but not for dinner.

bwbtWxPlYn0S_Xss59a8dA.text: I came here a month or 2 ago and I keep forgetting to leave a review. My husband and I really enjoy eating out and love to try the new places in the Pittsburgh food scene and Superior Motors is such a great addition! I love the interior how open it is and the seating was so comfortable. I really think they captured the Pittsburgh vibe of eating out. People don't want to necessarily get fancy to eat unique tasty fancy food. There weren't tons of options to try as pescatarians we really enjoyed what we ordered and look forward to coming back as they update their seasonal menu!

4Rt7YrpS9KxA3CU_oqhMuw.text: I had a lot of fun with this dinner. My experience with the staff wasn't the best. I've read that they hire folks from the local depressed area of Braddock. They were nice enough, but may need time to perfect their new trade. Our waitress was not the most attentive and frequently forgot to refill water.   I thought the food so good. We had for starters the octopus. Which was nothing less than amazing. The preparation just fit so perfectly with the taste of the meat. The raw scallops were so tasty and last was the foie gras. It was sweeter, almost like a foie gras pie; but delicious.  For our mains my wife had the beef and I had the lamb. Both meats were cooked to perfection. I think the beef was better, it has a nice smoked flavor. The lamb was good, but the preparation was so delicious.   They had a nice wine selection, maybe a few to many roses. The cocktails were great. The beer selection left a little to be desired. I always wonder why beer is so plain at these places. Where are the DIPA's and imperial stouts?

919JJ9N1883b5Rymr27Ecg.text: I was so excited to try this place out. Superior Motors is in a very edgy neighborhood and the contrast (a pretentious restaurant in a neighborhood peppered with shootings/stabbings just blocks away) felt very off-putting and voyeuristic to me.    I will say that I love the decor and was really impressed by all the artwork. I wish the creativity was translated into the food. We had the duck, pork, and beef. I thought the composition of the pork dish was very focused, but did not understand why they plated the entire dish in one corner of a plate. It helps sometimes to spread the ingredients out and allow them to breathe a little. I also wasn't too excited about the marmalade that accompanied the duck.   To finish, I had the tart, which was an interpretation of key lime pie. I thought the dessert had really good balance. I love it when a dessert is rich and satisfying but doesn't taste sweet.   Overall I'd say I have mixed feelings about this place. It is a very unique experience, but could be so much more.

Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States

oqsYneFl1CUPCNJRgt6ehQ.text: Some people laughed when I mentioned going to an expensive restaurant in Braddock, but the minute you step inside, you won't remember the neighborhood at all. The restaurant is really well designed - I love the vibe.  Almost EVERYTHING on the menu looked great and everything we got was delicious. If you want amazingly good food and are willing to pay for it, this is a must try. Our service was amazing. Though we drank a lot of water (and some alcoholic beverages), our glasses were never empty. The waitress was able to explain everything on the menu (we had some questions) perfectly and offered tips we might not have thought about. If you're looking for a nice meal at a fancy restaurant with great service, give this a try!  (One minor warning for those with nut allergies - almost everything on the menu seemed to have peanuts or tree nuts.)

ftMMa6P_td2_0ING9Q1EGA.text: I know what you're thinking. "Braddock?? It's sketchy over there and it's too far. Not worth it." Oh but that is so not the case. Trust me, you wont regret it one bit. Superior Motors is such a gem nestled in the rough. Truly, I was absolutely blown away after my first bite. Wow. Everything we had here was just outstanding.   I came here during restaurant week so I think my portions were a little smaller than usual (so don't be discouraged by my pictures of such small plates). Because of this, I was able to sample three absolutely phenomenal dishes as well as the full plates my husband ordered. Ocean trout tartare, fried squid, sage cavatelli, beef, and veal. Of these, my favorite was the fried squid and if I had to pick my least favorite, it'd be the veal. Overall, though, each dish was so inventive, intricate, and absolutely stunning.   Overall, Superior Motors is a very well-thought-out restaurant. The whole experience here is definitely worth the trek to Braddock!

0x6qXNhCYC7XQncr2G6Y3g.text: This is one of the most over rated restaurants in Pittsburgh. We were so excited to try - seeing there is a $100 cancelation fee for canceling after Thursday for a Saturday reservation- but the whole experience turned out to be horrible. The main problem was the cold chicken THIGH...as well as the microscopic soft shell crab served over ramen.  We were told we had to order all 3 courses at once so the food was timed properly, but the joke was on us! The food came out cold and like it was a food dish double in "Honey I Shrunk the Kids". We could get more fish off a baby goldfish!! No flavor in any of the dishes except the steak tartar which was actually very good.  The cocktails were below average, super short pours and nothing special.  The service is inexperienced and not attentive which appear to be culinary students with no oversight. Over 20 mins between courses with nobody to be found.  The manager was very nice when we expeessed our concerns. He's great and a good restaurant should pick him up. 13/10 do not recommend this restaurant. For the cost, expect I expected amazing but this restaurant did not deliver it, not even close.

FYhEwEzDG-QHQyzLFPzOsw.text: I stopped by here a couple of Thursdays ago with my wife and my parents for my birthday dinner.  Superior Motors is one of those restaurants that I have been looking forward to trying ever since it was introduced maybe 3 years ago.  The slow progress of building it and its location in Braddock meant that it wasn't a place to head to for just any meal.  That's why I waited until my birthday to give it a try.  We had reservations for 7:15 and arrived to the restaurant right around that time.  It was busy inside and we waited about 15 minutes for our table to open up. Whoever it was that was working the front of the house on this day, you could tell he was really busting his butt doing anything he could to help the servers and hostess.  I loved seeing that!  In any case, the inside of the restaurant is certainly interesting.  The walls are brick which gives it an industrial feel and then there are paintings on the wall which my mom thought elementary school students could do. Haha.  They were better than that but certainly more of the abstract variety.  For dinner on this evening I decided to start off with the crispy pig face appetizer while the rest of the table decided to split the smoked seitan.  The menu described my crispy pig face as coming with vegetarian boudin noir (not sure how that works), black truffle and mustard while the seitan came with popcorn, mango and spruce.  Both were beautiful whenever they came to our table.  My crispy pig face ended up being quite good as it was fried into a rectangular object which ended up having a really intense pork flavor to it.  I especially enjoyed dipping it into the mustard.  Last but certainly not least was the boudin noir which sort of had the consistency and flavor profile of stove top stuffing although not exactly the same. I was also able to try some of the smoked seitan and loved both the smokiness of it and the mango on top of it.  Then for my entree I went with the duck while my wife ordered the salmon.  My duck came with Swiss chard, cashew and rhubarb while my wife's salmon came with white asparagus, sorrel, hazelnut and hollandaise.  I was especially excited about mine as duck and rhubarb are too of my favorite flavors and you so rarely see them together.  Thankfully it didn't disappoint as my meal was delicious.  The duck ended up coming two ways with probably a half of a breast as well as some confit and both parts were cooked perfectly.  Meanwhile the cashew added some texture to the dish while the rhubarb added that sweetness and sourness that it is known for.  My only complaint about the dish was that there wasn't more of it, haha.  My wife and parents also really enjoyed all of their dishes.  The bottom line for me is that I would head back here again in the future.  Superior Motors really lives up to its wait for me as all of the food was beautifully plated and delicious.

tbnKTend8YxtIYFNEdRurA.text: Just one of those eternally-memorable meals. Mezcal cocktail - dragonfruit and salt and pepper - was toe-turling.  Rye punch with the luxardo cherry and orange peel was light and herbacious and oh-so satisfying.  Absolute bests: * Braised lamb with hidden crisped sweetbreads and an orange sauce that, I swear, originated from an angel * Fried pig's head with blood pudding was an umami explosion, like a tiny bite of the entirety of your mom's Christmas dinner, rolled into one. * Peekytoe Crab with fresh, sweet corn was the most gentle, sweet, cool, palate-cleansing dish I have ever had * Veal with rhubarb was such an innovative flavor pairing, meant to be, more compatible than Kristen Bell and Dax Shepherd; has reignited my interest in both ingredients. * Pretzel Salad was both comforting and elevated and completely blew my mind * THE YUZU GANACHE OMG OMG OMG OMG uh, normally, the dessert isn't supposed to be the best part of the meal, but the ganache was impossibly silky and the yuzu ice cream was utterly sublime.  Complaining for no reason, other than it's expected on Yelp: The only ones that I could have taken or left were the korean rice cakes, black cod and the cobia, which would have been both objectively outstanding anywhere else, but the bar was raised too damn high. (and in the case of korean rice cakes, I just think that I like them cheap and dumb.  Like at all-you-can-eat KBBQ-style.  It felt so wrong eating fancy ones).  Server was charming and so knowledgeable - we asked for a white wine recommendation that would work with our entire meal, and he smartly advised us to the Viogner, which was meaty and present and golden and worked with literally everything.  We regretted not getting the duck because the wine had a hint of game in it that would have sent us through the roof.  I would honestly take a special trip back to Pittsburgh, just to enjoy this establishment once again.  Hard success, great business - I'd give it more than five stars if I could.

tfblmg0J2Zm8dxhsJiL4vQ.text: Food was amazing. The salmon (first) is the best salmon I've ever had. Our server was great too. Personable and knowledgeable. Can't wait to go back!

8_de3wdPxiIuEyv79DgGGQ.text: I have been wanting to go to Superior Motors since it opened. I was so excited that I was able to a table during restaurant week.  My husband and I were both rather underwhelmed!  My entree came with 2 scallops, just 2 and they were cold in the middle.  My husband opted for the steak which also was cold and a small portion.  We found the food just average and do not understand all the hype.

FEt-lhMMVPwvYMHuq1b7eA.text: My husband and I visited Superior Motors for an epic date night that we will long remember. I prefaced the visit by calling and speaking with Chris Clark, the GM, who asked a few questions about our preferences and then spoke to Chef Sousa. My request was that we didn't want to make any decisions - that we wanted to be surprised and eat until we busted open.  We went a bit early, which I highly recommend, so we could walk around a bit. SM is located directly across the street from the USS Mon Valley Works Edgar Thomson Plant. I loved that the restaurant really fits into its surroundings and does not overwhelm the neighborhood. Arriving early will also give you a chance to check out the interior and grab a drink.  Chris met us when we arrived; and, knowing how busy the reservation book was, recommended that we just sit at the bar. This couldn't have been a more spot on recommendation for us, as we thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The bartenders were not just friendly but awesome wait staff themselves. They paired all of our dishes with the perfect choices of IPA, prosecco, saki, and a Greek red wine.  The food...oh, the food...  We started with what turned out to be the only challenging dishes for the both of us. My husband had the diver scallop with buckwheat noodles and cuddlefish ink. I had the cobia, with freeze dried avocado noodles (YUM! I could eat a whole bowl!), and a tomatillo/jalapeno/cilantro broth. What was challenging for the both of us was just that we hadn't ever had such unique raw seafood preparations before - so it was just an overwhelming starter - but delicious nevertheless.  For the next course, I had black cod with sunchokes, kale, and leek. I'll mention here that Chef Sousa's dishes are always loaded with fresh veg - and the veg are always prepared with multiple cooking techniques to keep the flavors and textures constantly evolving based on what's on your fork next. My husband had the salmon, with white asparagus, sorrel, hazelnut, and a hollandaise. Again, the textures and flavors here were morphed with every bite.  For the next course, I had a chicken dish that was so reminiscent of my Nana's funsei (a South American dish) that I got all choked up with nostalgia - but I still managed to gobble down what was an outstanding chicken dish. My husband had the veal with ricotta, asparagus, and fiddleheads. What an incredible combination of meat, cheese, and veg! I could have eaten a whole platter of this.  Overall, Chris and Chef Sousa picked the ideal combination of dishes for us: challenging, comforting, and downright delicious all around. At this point, we were pretty full from cruising through the menu; however, the pasta was calling to me...  We ordered one last savory course to share - the house made pappardelle with egg, watercress, and cauliflower. As a carnivore myself, I couldn't have loved this veg dish more. It was like the great red wine we were sipping: delicate and still packing a bold flavor punch.  Any regular diner would have thrown in the napkin - but not us! We finished our journey with the ganache, yuzu, lime dessert. Chocolate with citrus is probably one of my favorite combos so I was a happy camper.   I will warn the frugal spender: Superior Motors is quite pricey; however, you 100% get what you pay for, which, in this case, is superior service, libations, and food. And if that's not enough, remember what Chef Sousa is doing for the neighborhood and Braddock Youth Project kids; about how he both reclaimed and re-visioned the history of the building itself; and, the fact that products are sourced from area vendors.  It is easy to see why 'Food & Wine' considers Superior Motors to be the Restaurant of the Year. I look forward to seeing Chef Sousa continue to grow. Cheers!

xZN_syZysqvel0M_gN3-6Q.text: Firstly the venue was amazing, right next to a working steel mill. I thought we were lost when we were driving to the middle of nowhere for a nice dinner. The building itself is very industrial and fit the area well. The service was excellent, and the menu was highly creative. The food was all really well done and worth the adventure for dinner. Would go back for sure.

Or2U9EDD_zRFICzPCs-2Qw.text: Superior Motors...Superior Food....Superior Experience  From the moment we entered the door for our Anniversary Dinner, the staff was ready and made us feel like special customers.The host (I didn't get his name) welcomed us with a "happy Anniversary" and a smile. Our server, Erin, was warm, cheerful and informative, answering all our questions with aplomb.   We were first served a free celebratory glass of champagne and settled down to one of the best meals of our lives.  The Bourbon Cocktail, flavored with coffee rum, was a delicious starter.   We started with the Beef Tartare, served on a perfect cracker-like bread, and the Crispy Pig Face (no it's not shaped like a face or a pig), savory pork with a beautiful berry and mustard sauce.  For our main, I had the Duck entree, perfectly flavored and cooked to a sublime medium rare, while my wife had the Grass Fed Beef, so tender it melted.  I don't recall the details of our dessert, but let's just say it was a perfect topper to the meal.  We were treated at the end to an "anniversary" tour of the kitchen. Fascinating!  It was a great experience all around. The staff was awesome, the food sublime.We will definitely return!

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. To the left - beef tartare.  To the right - Crispy Pig Face
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. To the left: Duck entree To the right: grass fed beef

Mc6CsZWBFosRzhwtzfBaZQ.text: We had been waiting YEARS for superior motors to open, and by the time it had, we had already moved away! Fortunately, we we able to make time to come out here on our last trip to Pittsburgh.   The food was delicious. I loved Salt of the Earth, and was really looking forward to Kevin Sousa's next venture. In our group we had the octopus, hamachi, almost all the entrees and the pavlova and bread pudding desserts, and saw him working in the open concept kitchen while we were enjoying our meal.  A couple things:  I had issues with our main waitress throughout the night. We were in a group of 6 and we ask a lot of questions when it comes to food and satisfying everyone's palette. She came off and very condescending and more like we were intruding on her restaurant, rather than welcoming us to share this experience with her. We did not feel like sentiment with other waiters and waitresses who came by to collect plates. This was very off-putting and there was really nothing we could do about it.   Cocktails were not good. My watermelon gin drink tasted like watered down gin. I had one sip and didn't touch it for the rest of the night. I had hoped that our waitress would notice and offer a new one but  it just sat there full until our check came. Our general experience with her for the entire night was really bizarre.   The interior decor is really nice but the elevated tables around the perimeter of the restaurant have HUUUUGE tables. Really nice and spacious but hard to reach certain plates. Also when our waitress handed us new plates in between I went to grab mine but she wouldn't let go and stared at me during this power play until I let go so SHE could put my plate down. So weird.   I want to say that the food was worth the money but this particular experience, having to deal with our waitress, was not. I hope to give SM another chance, but don't feel particularly inclined to.

9d590dYvZm4ZFK14CPaK6w.text: Food: Good - Flavors are present and presentations are great. Excellent unique options though the menu are limited and very little proportions at time.  Service: Excellent - Very professional and courteous. Even have alcohol and menu samples at times.  Overall: Recommend - Definitely worth the drive, you won't be disappointed. Prices are a little steep.

x8IsKUHkl1YWWYX6HKxzZA.text: I want this review to be better, but as I sit here typing, I can't in good faith give them more than 2 stars. The fact is that a restaurant can serve the most innovative, flawlessly prepared food, but it won't matter if the experience is tainted.   We decided to celebrate my grandmother's 93rd birthday here, and brought a cake to celebrate. Well, I guess a write up in the New York Times means you don't have the time or the willingness to cut the cake for your guests. Instead we were met with a "we don't serve outside food. The manager should have told you." This was after the manager took the cake himself and refrigerated it for us! I get it, you're riding high from your review, but lest you forget, this is a customer service industry and continuing to promote an attitude of "we can't be bothered because we're so amazing" will not work forever.   People want to be treated like you care even a little bit about them, not to be treated like the next person in line needs to be sat at our table. The food almost becomes an accessory to the experience when you foster a culture of pretentious and cold treatment. Unfortunately it's not the quality of the food that I'm taking with me from the experience; rather, the almost nonexistent customer service.

eXz-TDE3VcV0Ii2Ww0xJdQ.text: We did not have a reservation and actually went with the idea to listen to the "live music" that was advertised and if possible have a drink / small plate.  The music on this particular night consisted of a man moaning into a microphone with a back up moaner behind him.  It was bad.  However we were able to snag a table and dine and the food was fantastic.  We sampled the chicken thigh, gnocchi, and crab as well as the yogurt cake for dessert and coffee.  Everything was so different and the tastes equally interesting.  It would have been nice to have bread to dip into the remaining sauce but the waitress said that their restaurant "tends to cater to those that want to avoid carbs."   I like SM for a restaurant experience where I can have just enough and it's interesting.  Seemed to us to be somewhat romantic with the decor, lighting and way the servers deliver the food and vamoose ..however there were groups of families and college students.  Great place.

ZHuDmKaTOyq_BjiK0drhOg.text: Simply the best restaurant in Pittsburgh. Kevin Sousa is an amazing chef who has continued to expand his repertoire. He and his staff have thought through a million details and have come up with a restaurant experience that is deeply satisfying.   I would invite you to leave your preconceptions aside. Superior Motors is challenging, flavorful, thrilling and thoughtfully conceived. If you are not interested in being challenged by new flavors and provocative food expressions...save your money and go elsewhere. But if you would like to try bold flavor combinations and an adventure in dining, by all means, don't miss eating here.   The dining room is carefully laid out, and it does not feel crowded. Our server was attentive and passionate. She was obviously well trained and loves her job. We gave her a ridiculous 40% tip and she earned every penny.   Each dish led to some new discovery. Not just, novelty, however, but, gratifying, refreshing and delicious.   So I really miss Salt of the Earth, it was my favorite restaurant. However Superior Motors is...well, superior!

SAhk2os42onffJcE4qQeqA.text: The buzz surrounding Superior Motors ultimately worked against it. Driving 40 minutes to dine at an expensive restaurant as hyped as this one primed me for the best meal of my life when in reality it wasn't even the best meal of my week. The food was all properly prepared but none of it was exciting. The flavors were fairly bland and nothing left me with a lasting impression. They also crammed our party into an awkward table that made conversation difficult. Given the price and distance, I would not recommend Superior Motors.

YhdSrlFOPMEB-kNyHgnffA.text: Was really looking forward to this place but it was really disappointing. I love the local and community integration concepts but the execution was bad. Soup was 7/10. I could see how some people might like the bean and eggplant salad but no one at our table of 4 enjoyed it. Drink served with a ton of crushed ice in a short glass should have been served with a skinny straw so you don't get ice all over your face with every sip. Lamb and chicken were delicious. Grouper was bland and the potato came out cold. Beef was okay but had a bug in it from not cleaning the mushrooms well enough. They gave us that entree for free and then tried to make nice by "giving us a tour of the place" which involved the manager letting us walk 5 feet into the kitchen. The manager then proceeded to make my aunt feel bad for not telling him that she didn't enjoy her meal before we paid and said there was now nothing he could do about it. (How about a "here's an appetizer for free on us next time", buddy?). I was super excited for the desserts but the pavlova was cloyingly sweet and the pound cake was just okay. Also, poor choice on the faucet selection in the bathrooms. 3 of the 4 at our table couldn't figure out how to get water from it and once they figured it out had to help 2 other strangers with it too. That's a whole bunch of disappointment in one night. Hopefully they can pull it together to make some improvements and live up the hype.

1hVLLaTjD0N-om1aMYDvbQ.text: I'm writing this review one month after I first visited Superior Motors. I was a fan of Kevin Souza's Salt of the Earth and I was pretty disappointed when they shut down. It took a while for SM to open, then it was featured on Anthony's Bourdain and that discouraged me to go because I figured it would be packed with curious followers of the CNN show. But I was dragged there by friends on a night out. Glad I was. Atmosphere is great, they did an amazing job with the decoration. Instead of hiding the views to an old USS steel mill across the street they actually integrated into the restaurant using large glass windows. The result is pretty amazing, a surreal view of an old, grim, dark part of the neighborhood from the modern, cozy and warm dinning area of the restaurant. Food and service are great as expected from Kevin and his team, I had venison for the first time ever and it was delicious. We were a large group and the consensus was it is pretty damn good. Recommended.

siHw-Bjcyg35hEYHKYuG5A.text: Superior Motors can do no wrong in my book right now.  I visited on Saturday with a couple friends for Restaurant week!    We were seated at the bar. At first I was disappointed to be seated at the bar...but as the meal continued - i was glad. We made friends with the wait staff/bartenders behind the bar.  It was great!  They recommended drinks, food, etc.  Now...regarding the food.  All the yum was happening during restaurant week. (And all the time!)  It was suggested that we add one more side - which we did.  If you are visiting Superior Motors I highly suggest getting the smoked potatoes.  I believe they change them with the seasons - but they (as they have been in the past) are my absolute favorite.  I will order them every single time i visit - restaurant week or not.    All the additional food for restaurant week was amazing (it always is!) Superior motors never disappoints.  You should be there, Now.

Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Scallops
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Chocolate ganache with peach marmalade

NyKuhUDNOgZ2JJOJwDh3QQ.text: We enjoyed Pittsburgh's restaurant week at Superior Motors. Kevin Sousa and the restaurant were featured on Anthony Bordain's Parts Unknown. It's great food. A local garden in Braddock, where the restaurant is located, provides the produce. The dishes are simple but bold in flavor. The preparations allow the flavors of the fresh ingredients to come through. He trains and hires many local young people from Braddock, an economically challenged area. It's a great concept and dining experience.  We had the restaurant week prix fixe. Everything was cooked to perfection. I had the NY Koji strip steak, my wife had the scallops. Both were great (see the photos for the descriptions of the food).

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. COURSE THREE: Chocolate Ganache with Peach Marmalade Served with a Sweet Corn Mousse, Guajillo Chiles and Corn nut-Coconut Crumble
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. We added a couple of courses to the prix fixe. This was the gnocci with tomatoes, beans, kale, and cashews.
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. They serve some locally crafted beer, so I ordered a Helltown brown ale rather than a glass of cabernet.

qrNbqBg1IFnoe6nbG9mWLg.text: A revitalization is going on in Braddock and this very trendy restaurant is in the forefront. The atmosphere is industrial warehouse beautifully designed, looking out across the street at an old US Steel plant. So I guess it fits in the vibe.   It features a tapas focused menu. The problem with tapas for us is that we never really leave full without dropping plenty of coin. And with 4 people having 2 rounds of $12 cocktails it pumps up the bill quickly. That said the quality, taste and and presentation was very good.   While I might recommend it For the experience, I doubt that we would return.

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Pricey for what it was IMO
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States

oMJdExry6_KolHQgdAGFGw.text: I am biased for sure, because I am a huge ) Sousa fan. We've watched the progress of construction over the past couple of years. The beer selection is well-curated. The food is fabulous. I would put the space, the vibe and the food up against any restaurant in any other city - NYC, Chicago, etc. Because it's pricey, I probably won't take the whole family there as often as I'd like, but hope to go back soon with my husband.   August 2019 Restaurant Week Update: We try to visit Superior Motors for every Restaurant Week. I have no complaints about the quality of the food or the service (or the cocktails). But the portion sizes were small by comparison to past Restaurant week offerings. This is not a problem for me, because I tend to prefer smaller plates, but overall this was not so much of a "deal" like we have experienced in the past at  Superior Motors or at other fine restaurants this year. If I were rating the meal I had tonight, overall I would give it four and one-half stars for the small portions.

Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Seared scallops

bm2FGUKe7XnTPfbQk-Gkiw.text: Pros: good service, interesting menu items, convenient parking, nice ambience  It was hard to enjoy my meal because there were around 3 fruit flies just hanging around our table the whole time. The cheese with bread and dried fruits was good, but not anything special or worth trying here. I thought the shrimp appetizer was interesting - it came with corn salad and "compressed" watermelon, and seemed very well thought out in terms of flavor combination and plating. However, it didn't taste as good as the concept seemed and the whole idea of compressed watermelon was just kind of funny to me.  I had the salmon dish as my entree, and I really enjoyed it. The salmon was very crispy on the outside, and soft and tender on the inside. The dish included salad, pickled foods, and grains, and had a really nice balance of salty, savory, and sweet. A lot of the menu seemed to have influences from Asian cuisines, and I thought the food was very unique.

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Duck
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Salmon
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States. Shrimp

_hu5_xOHriEqJQ0sFZHj8A.text: I think after this meal, my thoughts on small plates have changed. I usually just think they're pointless and an easy way to over charge people.  But this meal was amazing.  There were 3 of us and we had a total of 8 dishes (including 1 side dish and 2 desserts) and our total was $160. We were all completely full after also.  To start we got the soup, the beef tartar and the gnocchi. All were Incredible. I was really wanting the tuna tartar but they were out of tuna so that was a bummer. But still it was amazing. The gnocchi was out of this world. I wanted 6 plates of it. For entrees we had the pork belly, salmon, chicken, and a side of potatoes. The salmon was the only dish we didn't like. None of us liked it really. The flavors were a bit odd and very very bitter.   Dessert we had a chocolate fudge type thing with popcorn crumbles on it(my fave) and the yogurt cake.   Honestly I'll go back without a question. I do wish the place was a little more inviting. The host was kinda eh, and the servers were nice but kinda felt a bit cold.

Ody1ZuiIy-AVj2jqywT5ZQ.text: If gentrification had a visual dictionary entry it should be this establishment. Trendy, eclectic restaurant in an otherwise poor and lifeless area--the road is rather bumpy and there is basically absolutely nothing else around (but I bet their rent is cheap!).  I didn't come particularly hungry, so I had a small dish with some apricot, cheese, and some more goodness. It was light and fruity, basically exactly what I was looking for. And the entree was a beef dish with some asparagus and some other veggies around it, with two different sauces including a mole sauce. Both dishes were tasty, and the beef in particular was cooked very nicely. For the quality the price is reasonable.  The place is so far out of the way of anything else that I'd say you should go when you're in the mood for a ride--and have confidence in your tires.

wk6PUp9f4jn_Fpy17HZj6A.text: A very nice place, but not the best option for vegetarians. We got, in order of favorite to least, the kimchi rice cakes, potatoes, carrots with cheese and hazelnuts, and seitan with beets and lentils. The seitan was pretty un-special, but you can get a meat option ("sweetbreads") which is maybe worth the money. These were the only 4 vegetarian options on the menu that day.  We also got a mushroom-infused chocolate cake, which I again found not as exciting as I expected. I did love a lot of things!! The staff was exceptional, and service was so speedy. They have a special pairing where they pair two wines made with the same grape from different vineyards- this time one was from South Africa and one from Texas! That was great and delicious. I also loved the atmosphere inside and that they labeled the vegan options.  Overall, I wouldn't make the drive out from Pittsburgh again when there are tons of vegetarian options close to home.

photos.caption: Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States
Photo of Superior Motors - Braddock, PA, United States

3w54JkGE1J0iPFkAdfCmTw.text: A beautiful restaurant! what a great job they did designing this space, in such an unsuspecting area. We sat at the bar and had a view into the open kitchen where we loved watching the delicious and creative food being made. The bartender was very nice and answered all our questions. I had a cocktail that was so delicious, I will definitely be driving all the way back to have another sometime soon. It was some concoction of Maggie's farm rum in the best way possible.   We shared 4 plates including the pork chop, cauliflower, and potatoes. Everything was beautifully plated and tasty. You do have to order quite a few plates to end the meal feeling full. The portions are small and food is very unique!

qeYuzTeQZb2CkGBz3R7uDg.text: I went to Superior Motors tonight for their collaboration dinner with OddFellows ice cream. Each of the six dishes had ice cream integrated somehow.   There were four savory dishes that progressively got better. The first dish was green apple bonito sorbet with tuna and uni. I have to say, it was not enjoyable at all. The food tasted really fresh and the presentation was beautiful. However, the flavors did not blend and it just tasted like ice cream and fish. The second dish, was burnt toast ice cream and celeriac. This dish was tasty however, the ice cream just seemed like it was thrown into to dish. The edamame ice cream dish was next and included venison tartare. This dish was good however, the venison was a little too spicy for my liking. The final dish was the foie gras ice cream with squab. The squab was cooked a little too rare however, the foie gras ice cream was very rich and full of flavor.   The two desserts were the best part of the meal. The flavor blended very well. There were really good flavors and textures.    Atmosphere: the dining room has an industrial feel inside. Looking outside the window, there is a steel factory across the street. This was really beautiful aesthetically but concerning once you I outside the restaurant. The air smelled funny and a little nauseating.   I will review this place again, once I dine and enjoy their regular menu. For being best restaurant according Pittsburgh magazine, along with other accolades, I was expecting more.

EtH1g6-7_Yez8d12mR-sZw.text: No. Just no. Again, here I am with an unpopular opinion, but this place is overrated to the max. We came during restaurant week because I've been dying to make it out that way- and what better time?  I'll start by saying that the staff is incredible. The host, our server, everyone was warm and welcoming.   The restaurant week menu consisted of a potato appetizer, a steak, and a chocolate dessert. There was also a "specialty" drink for restaurant week.   To start, the rule was if one of us ordered the restaurant week menu, everyone at the table had to order it as well. Like, what? How is that even a thing- and if it is, why is that not mentioned in their restaurant week advertising? What if I just drove my vegetarian friend 35 mins, and now no one can order any restaurant week foods because there is only one option and it's meat?  The steak was chewy and gross - even my husband wouldn't finish mine. The potato appetizer ended up being the highlight. Such a disappointment.  Then, they are out of their specialty drink- okay, there is a replacement and it sounds decent. End of the story is that I paid $11 for a substitute drink that was basically water with a slice of pineapple.  Only cool part was the friendly staff and the fact that they display the record of the music that is playing at the time.  I was so angry that I got fancied up, drove all the way across Pittsburgh, only to be disappointed.

dip4H2zEHo0zoVddi1x8Ww.text: Celebrated my birthday at Superior Motors. Creative dishes. Good flavor. Well balanced. I had the watermelon non-spirit drink, chilled yogurt berry soup, salad, walleye, and meringue dessert. I would definitely return. The food was amazing. The only thing that could have made it better was the an accommodation for my walleye dish as I am allergic to gluten. It would have been nice to have been offered a GF starch substitute for the farro (e.g. rice).

KKAc-Dk3p2v4kpMsCMEqfA.text: This restaurant has been on my list for some time to try, and maybe I was over expectant, but in the end the experience was nothing more than mediocre at best (at a fairly hefty price).  The wait (even though we had a reservation) was annoying, the waiter asked us 15 times if our mediocre dishes were okay, and in the end after ordering an app, an entree and a dessert, I was still hungry (and I generally don't eat a lot).  Also I'm not sure why our dessert for a toddler came on a giant plate?

lJc04oXD3CNuaEjbG_cx2Q.text: I applaud the owners for making a bold decision having a restaurant next to a steel mill. Ride to the restaurant is adventurous: Welcome to Pittsburgh, Authentic Steel City Feel!  I choose to give them 5 stars for food, service, ambiance and creativity.  Will be back. We enjoyed their food tremendously. I had to have 2 of their Beet-Martinis...best I've ever had.
